title: **Lavender Tallow Balm: What My Skin Did When I Quit the Fancy Stuff
body:
Okay, so. My face was a disaster last winter. Like, flaky and tight and just… angry. I was using that La Roche-Posay Lipikar Balm AP+M stuff. You know the one. Everyone online says it’s the holy grail for dry skin. Cost me like thirty bucks at the drugstore. Felt like spreading cold glue on my cheeks. It just sat there. My skin drank it up and was still thirsty five minutes later. I’d wake up and it was like I’d never put anything on. I was so annoyed. I had this whole little skincare routine, a whole shelf of bottles, and my skin just did not care. It was a Tuesday, I think. Really cold. I was staring at my sad reflection and I just thought, *this is stupid*.

That’s when I started looking at other things. Weird things. I kept seeing people talk about tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I mean, come on. That sounds like something your great-grandmother would have used before they invented… everything. But I was desperate. And curious. So I ordered this whipped tallow balm with lavender from some little shop on Etsy. Made in France, from grass-fed cows. It arrived in this simple jar. No crazy packaging. I opened it and just… sniffed it. Smelled like lavender. But real lavender. Not the fake candle kind. More like the plant itself, if you crushed it in your hand. Earthy. Herbal. I was skeptical. Big time.

## **How I Started Smearing Beef Fat on My Face**

Look, the idea is weird. I’m not gonna lie. You’re telling me to put rendered cow fat on the same skin I’m trying to make look nice. But then I read a bit. Tallow is basically like our skin’s own sebum. The oils we make. So it absorbs. Like, really absorbs. It doesn’t just coat the top and call it a day. My brain went, “Huh.” The commercial stuff I was using? Full of water, emulsifiers, preservatives. It’s designed to feel nice going on, but that’s about it. The tallow is just… food. For your skin. No water, so nothing to evaporate and leave you dry. It made a stupid kind of sense.

First time I tried it, I was nervous. Texture was thick. Like, really thick. You have to warm it up between your fingers. Then it melts. It goes on sort of… oily? But not greasy. It just sinks in. Doesn’t feel slick. I put it on before bed. The lavender smell was strong in the jar but on my skin it was just this calm, quiet smell. Not perfumey. I fell asleep pretty fast, actually. Forgot about it.

Woke up the next morning. My face wasn’t tight. That was the first thing. No tight, itchy feeling. It was just… my face. Soft. Not shiny. Not dry. Just normal. I poked my cheek. It felt like skin is supposed to feel. I was shocked. I didn’t expect that. At all. I kept using it. Every night. My hands were cracked from the cold too, so I started rubbing the extra on my knuckles. They stopped hurting. The cracks healed. I was like, okay. This is not a fluke.

## **What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does**

It’s not magic. It’s just… effective. Here’s the thing with natural vs commercial skincare for me now. The commercial lotion was doing a performance. It felt cool and creamy. It had a fancy name. It promised “72-hour hydration.” It was all show. The tallow balm just works. It’s boring. It’s one ingredient, plus some lavender oil. That’s it. But my skin knows what to do with it.

Winter is brutal here. The heat’s on, the air is dry. My elbows were like sandpaper. I’d put on my regular body lotion and an hour later I’d be scratching them. I started using a tiny bit of the tallow balm on them. Just at night. Took maybe three nights. They’re smooth now. Actually smooth. I don’t know the last time my elbows were smooth. Maybe when I was a kid?

And my face. The fine lines around my eyes, the ones that look worse when I’m dehydrated? They’re just… less. Not gone. I’m not twenty. But they’re not so pronounced. My skin just looks more relaxed. Plumped up. Not puffy, just… content. It’s the best natural moisturizer I’ve ever used, and I’ve tried a lot of the “clean” brands that cost three times as much. This stuff is simple. It’s almost anti-skincare. You’re not doing ten steps. You’re just giving your skin what it recognizes as food.

## **Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again?**

I’m on my second jar. I got one for my mom, too, because her hands get terrible eczema in the winter. She called me last week and was like, “What is in that stuff? My knuckles aren’t red anymore.” She was using some prescription cream before that. She’s a convert now.

I still have that big bottle of La Roche-Posay. It’s sitting under my sink. I use it on my legs sometimes, just so it doesn’t go to waste. But for my face and hands? It’s the tallow balm. Every night. It’s part of the routine now. Brush teeth, wash face, tallow balm. The lavender scent signals to my brain that it’s time to wind down. It’s become this little ritual. I look forward to it.

It’s not for everyone. If you want something that smells like a tropical vacation or feels like a cloud, this isn’t it. It’s a functional, honest product. It smells like herbs and earth. It feels like a rich oil that disappears. It works because it’s simple. My skin finally shut up and stopped complaining. That’s the biggest win.

Anyway. If you’re frustrated with your skin, if the fancy stuff isn’t cutting it, maybe give it a shot. I got mine from this Etsy shop that just makes the stuff in small batches. It feels good to use something so straightforward. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s the whole point, right?

---

## **Quick Questions I Get Asked**

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. It sounds wild, but it’s very similar to the oils our own skin produces. So it absorbs deeply instead of sitting on top. It’s like giving your skin something it actually knows how to use. Great for dry skin, eczema, even just winter roughness.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. And I can get clogged pores pretty easy. Because it’s so similar to our sebum, it seems to absorb cleanly. It doesn’t feel pore-clogging. It’s not heavy or greasy once it sinks in, which takes a minute or two.

**What does lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Like real lavender. Not a sweet perfume. It’s herbal, a little earthy, kinda green. It’s a calm smell. Not strong on the skin, but nice when you’re applying it. Very relaxing before bed.
